ContentClassification.TableReference: D. H. Shaw, “Mortality Experience Among the Lower Income Families in Éire”, Statistical and Social Inquiry Society of Ireland (Ireland, 1945). Accessed: July, 2014 from http://www.tara.tcd.ie/bitstream/handle/2262/5479/jssisiVolXVII489_503.pdf?sequence=1
ContentClassification.TableDescription: Irish Industrial Life Table. Minimum Age: 0 Maximum Age: 100
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: In September 1939, an amalgamation of a large volume of life assurance transacted in Ireland was completed from four Irish Offices. A very large number of existing current industrial assurance policies came under control of the amalgamation. Industrial insurance comprises assurance where the premiums in respect of such assurances are payable at intervals of less than two months and are collected by means of collectors. The convenience of weekly collection of premiums enables protection to individuals confined to the lower income industrial workers. The data for this study comes from the amalgamation scheme and covers the years 1943 and 1944. Methodology: Table synthesized from fitting the Urban Districts Irish Life Table of 1941 with the collected data. At the juvenile ages there has been a marked improvement in the control of diphtheria, measles, whooping cough and scarlet fever. Hence excess deaths among the poorer classes would reflect the difference in the degree of medical attention available. For ages 17 to 40 excess deaths may be mainly attributable to tuberculosis, pneumonia, heart diseases and accidents. In the working-class families, the preponderance of deaths due to tuberculosis gives rise to higher mortality than exhibited by the Urban Districts table. The excess mortality of the industrial classes suggested that an addition of one year should be made to the age under the Urban rates from 41 continuing this as far as 70 when an increased rating would be required. After age 70, the age rating required to follow the experience rises gradually by a fraction at each age to a maximum of 5½| years at age 80. An adequate modification for misstatement of age, common at advanced ages, could not be ascertained. The rating up in age was thus restricted to a maximum of 3½ years for age 75 to 93. Finally, further small adjustments in the rates were made to obtain better smoothness in the series at a few points. Data Transcription Errors: None. Data Certified: 07/2014
